content:
The success rates of these strategies can vary greatly depending on a range of factors, including the specific approach being taken, the local housing market, and the level of community involvement and support.

That being said, there have been some success stories. For instance:

- The Housing First model has been shown to be successful in reducing homelessness. According to a study by the National Alliance to End Homelessness, Housing First programs have achieved housing placement rates of 80-90% and retention rates of 80-90%.

- Inclusionary housing policies have been successful in creating affordable housing units in some cities. For example, a study by the Lincoln Institute of Land Policy found that inclusionary housing policies in Montgomery County, Maryland, had produced 5,000 affordable homes since 1974.

- Tax-funded programs that support affordable housing and homelessness services have also been successful in some cities. For example, Seattle's "Move In" program, which provides rental assistance to low-income families and individuals, has achieved a 99% success rate in helping people maintain housing stability.

Overall, while there is no one-size-fits-all solution to addressing affordable housing and homelessness, these strategies have shown promise in certain contexts and have the potential to be effective when implemented thoughtfully and with the necessary resources and community support.
